abstract.p: Sundews (Drosera) are carnivorous plants that capture prey using mucilage-producing glands with both secretory and absorptive functions. Within a remarkably diverse clade that includes the Venus flytrap (Dionaea), East Asian pitcher plants (Nepenthes), the African carnivore Triphyophyllum (which bears three leaf types, one sundew-like) and the non-carnivorous vine Ancistrocladus, sundews show striking chromosomal variation. We present chromosome-scale genome assemblies for Drosera regia and D. capensis, comparing them with genomes of relatives. Complex allopolyploidies are revealed that prohibit depiction as bifurcating phylogenies. Characterization of centromere sequences demonstrated holocentric and monocentric chromosomes in D. regia and D. capensis, respectively, with corresponding structural divergence. Chromosomal fusions in D. regia likely trace to a shared allohexaploid ancestor shared with the dodecaploid and highly rearranged D. capensis genome. This comparative framework highlights genomic plasticity in a carnivorous plant lineage that offers a valuable model for studying morphological and ecophysiological diversity, polyploidy and centromere variation in angiosperms.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Flowering plants have diversified into nearly every terrestrial habitat by evolving a wide array of physiological and morphological strategies to, among other adaptive features, acquire essential nutrients. Among the most striking deviations from typical angiosperm organization are carnivorous plants, which have repeatedly evolved the ability to trap and digest animal prey to supplement their nutrient intake, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus, in resource-poor environments1,2. The transition to carnivory involves dramatic shifts in leaf development3,4, repurposing of defense responses5,6, nutrient transport7,8, and enzymatic secretion8,9, including co-opting genetic pathways typically associated with plant immunity and senescence10–13.

Carnivory has evolved independently at least ten times across flowering plants, and within five different angiosperm orders2. These convergent origins have given rise to an impressive diversity of trap morphologies, including snap-traps, suction bladders, and pitfall-trapping pitchers2. Particularly striking is the convergent evolution of pitcher traps in three distantly related lineages that diverged over 100 million years ago, being separated by vast numbers of non-carnivorous taxa1. Two major carnivorous clades within Lamiales (e.g., Utricularia, Pinguicula, Genlisea) and Caryophyllales (e.g., Drosera, Dionaea, Nepenthes), respectively, each encompass a striking diversity of trap morphologies1,2, exemplifying some of the most profound evolutionary innovations among angiosperms.

Within Caryophyllales, the genus Drosera (sundews) comprises over 200 species that use a specialized adhesive flypaper-trapping strategy14. Their leaves are covered with mucilage-secreting glandular tentacles that immobilize and digest insect prey. Despite this basic structural uniformity in the genus, Drosera exhibits considerable ecological and morphological diversity. Moreover, closely allied genera include the snap-trapping Dionaea (Venus flytrap) and Aldrovanda (the waterwheel plant), the morphologically divergent flypaper trappers Triphyophyllum15–17 and Drosophyllum18,19, and a group of secondarily non-carnivorous lianas (Ancistrocladus, Habropetalum, Dioncophyllum)15, which together form an extraordinary evolutionary radiation spanning multiple functional transitions.

Beyond their ecological specializations, sundews are remarkable for their reported diversity in chromosomal and genomic architecture20–23. Cytogenetic studies have proposed that the genus contains both monocentric chromosomes (with a single, localized centromere) and holocentric chromosomes (in which centromeric function is distributed in patches along entire chromatids)20,22,23. However, these claims have remained contentious due to the minute size of sundew chromosomes, which complicates cytological observations, and a historical lack of genomic sequence data to validate centromere structure and function.

Recent work across diverse eukaryotes has underscored the central role of centromere organization in shaping genome architecture24–26. Features such as the distribution of genes and transposable elements, patterns of tandem repeats, histone modifications, and crossover localization during meiosis all contribute to large-scale chromosomal behavior24–27. In plants with holocentric chromosomes, chromosomal breakage and fusion events can be tolerated without loss of centromere function, potentially accelerating genome restructuring and enabling novel evolutionary trajectories24–26. Despite this, the evolutionary and mechanistic consequences of holocentricity remain poorly characterized in flowering plants.

Here, we present high-quality, chromosome-scale genome assemblies for two Drosera species: D. regia, a morphologically and phylogenetically distinct taxon usually considered sister to all other sundews28,29, and D. capensis, a more typical, phylogenetically derived and widely cultivated species30,31. These species differ not only in evolutionary placement but also in cytogenetic properties, with D. regia previously proposed to possess monocentric chromosomes20 and D. capensis reported to be holocentric28,32,33. They also differ in ploidy level, with D. regia inferred to be hexaploid (6x) and D. capensis tetraploid (4x)34, although these estimates have not previously been confirmed with genome-scale data.

Our assemblies reveal that both Drosera genomes are relatively small (<300 Mbp) and shaped by ancient polyploidy. Contrary to prior reports, our cytogenomic analyses affirm that D. regia possesses holocentric, as opposed to monocentric chromosomes, suggesting that this feature may be more widespread in the genus than previously recognized, and that the species’ post-hexaploid diploidization involved extensive chromosomal fusion events. In contrast, D. capensis unexpectedly displays monocentric chromosomes and a dodecaploid, ancestrally hexaploid genome characterized by substantial structural rearrangement and disrupted synteny relative to D. regia and other carnivorous Caryophyllales, including Dionaea, Triphyophyllum, Ancistrocladus and Nepenthes.

To further explore genomic architecture within the genus, we analyzed repetitive DNA content in both species and generated short-read data for 10 additional Drosera taxa. These data reveal lineage-specific variation in repeat dynamics, suggesting that centromere structure may influence patterns of genome evolution even among closely related species in a single genus. Together, our findings illuminate the complex evolutionary history of Drosera and its close relatives, providing new insight into the interplay between centromere biology, polyploidy, and genome architecture in one of the most morphologically and genomically dynamic plant lineages.

sec.title: Chromosome-scale sundew genomes
sec.p: We generated reference-quality genome assemblies for D. regia and D. capensis using a combination of PacBio SMRT and Illumina DNA sequencing, and Hi-C chromosome conformation capture (Extended Data Table 1). The number of large pseudochromosomal scaffolds in the D. capensis and D. regia assemblies matched their known haploid chromosome numbers, n=20 and n=17, respectively34 (Fig. 1). Our chromosome-level assemblies were annotated using RNA-seq data from D. capensis and other species (see Methods). Furthermore, we annotated 32,230 and 32,090 high-confidence gene models along the 17 and 20 pseudomolecules of D. regia and D. capensis, respectively, with BUSCO scores of 96.7% for D. regia and 94.8% for D. capensis (Extended Data Table 1).

sec.title: Genome architecture reveals contrasting centromere organization in sundews
sec.p: Several species of Drosera have been reported to have holocentric chromosomes with centromeres decentralized over the length of the chromosome15–18. We combined Hi-C contact maps with genome-wide repeat annotations to infer the centromeric organization of the D. capensis and D. regia chromosomes (Fig. 1a–h). The D. capensis Hi-C map displayed a classic monocentric architecture, showing distinct A (euchromatin) and B (heterochromatin) compartments, including some degree of a telomere-to-centromere interaction axis (Fig. 1a– b). Correspondingly, repeat profiling of D. capensis revealed a single, size-restricted region of satellite DNA (satDNA) probably marking the centromere, flanked by a high density of transposable elements in the pericentromeric region, tapering toward the telomeres, while genes were concentrated on the distal chromosome arms (Fig. 1c–d). In contrast, the D. regia chromosomes lacked large-scale compartmentalization and showed no telomere-to-centromere interaction axis in their Hi-C maps (Fig. 1e–f), suggesting a non-monocentric structure. The D. regia repeat landscape mirrored this difference: satellite DNA occurred as multiple short arrays dispersed along the chromosomes, and both transposable elements and genes were uniformly distributed, without the typical pericentromeric enrichment (Fig. 1g–h). These results are in close agreement with recent reports for other holocentric plants. As recently reported by Hofstatter, et al.20, the concept of chromosome arms does not apply to holocentric species; however, as centromeric function is ubiquitous, holocentricity can be inferred at the chromatin contact pattern level observed in Hi-C matrices, and by the spatial organization of the different types of sequences along chromosomes. At present, our inference of holocentricity in D. regia is not matched by other previously-assembled genomes of carnivorous Caryophyllales under study; for example, the Hi-C contact map of D. muscipula reflected a chromosomal architecture comparable to that of D. capensis, in contrast to previous non-genomic research that suggested holocentricity for Dionaea muscipula16 (Extended data Fig. 1).

sec.title: Genetic and epigenetic composition of centromeres in D. capensis and D. regia
sec.p: We analyzed the genomes of D. regia and D. capensis to identify CENH3, a centromere-specific variant of histone H3 that is essential for kinetochore assembly and exhibits remarkable sequence divergence across species24. We identified two copies of CENH3 in each genome and generated specific antibodies against their variable N-terminal tails (Extended data Fig. 2a). Immunostaining with the CENH3 antibodies showed distinct foci in D. capensis interphase nuclei, confirming monocentricity in this species (Fig. 2a). Surprisingly, no specific signal was detected in the interphase of D. regia (Fig. 2b). Because it has been shown in some holocentric species that CENH3 is not essential to centromere function25,26, we aimed to check for the presence of the kinetochore component protein KNL1, which has been reported to be conserved across different plant lineages27. Immunostaining with the KNL1 antibody in interphase nuclei of D. capensis showed distinct foci (Fig. 2c). However, once again, we failed to detect any specific KNL1 signal in D. regia (Fig. 2d). Immunostaining of D. capensis metaphase chromosomes using KNL1 showed signals confined to a single chromosomal region colocalized with α-tubulin, reinforcing the conclusion of monocentricity in this species (Fig. 2e–i). Despite the absence of KNL1 signals in D. regia, α-tubulin was found to bind along the entire extent of its mitotic chromosomes (Fig. 2j–m). Thus, contrary to previous reports, our results provided solid evidence for monocentricity in D. capensis, whereas holocentricity instead for D. regia17.

We next analyzed the chromosomal distribution of satellite DNA, a key component of centromere architecture, to further dissect the centromeric landscape in both species28,29. Even though satDNA is not strictly required for centromeric function, most eukaryotic centromeres are predominantly composed of tandem satDNA repeats30. In our analysis, we identified one main satDNA family in each genome, Cape71 (a tandem repeat with monomer length of 71 bp) in D. capensis and Regi90 (a tandem repeat with monomer length of 90 bp) in D. regia, that do not share significant sequence identity with each other (Extended data Fig. 2b).

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) using a probe for D. capensis-specific Cape71 satellite DNA revealed discrete centromeric signals on interphase nuclei and metaphase chromosomes, while pachytene chromosomes clearly showed a single cluster of Cape71 repeats in each chromosome (Fig. 2n-s), confirming the presence of monocentric chromosomes in D. capensis. In contrast, the D. regia-specific repeat Regi90 is found as numerous dispersed foci in interphase nuclei (Figure 2t). Remarkably, Regi90 signals were found to form line-like signals in condensed mitotic metaphase chromosomes in D. regia (Fig. 2u-w). Indeed, Regi90 shows a similar behavior as recently reported for holocentromeric repeats in beaksedges35,36. Moreover, during meiosis we observed several foci of Regi90 repeats along highly stretched pachytene chromosomes in D. regia (Fig. 2x-y). The Regi90 repeat was also found irregularly distributed in short arrays (10-20 kb) across all D. regia chromosomes (Extended data Fig. 2c). This pattern of Regi90 repeats is intriguing as it resembles the pattern observed for repeat-based holocentromeres reported in Rhynchospora20 despite the fact that we could not detect centromere-specific proteins on D. regia chromosomes.

sec.title: Differential satellite DNA evolution reflects centromere architecture in Drosera
sec.p: We generated phylogenetic trees based on Regi90 and Cape71 sequences throughout the D. regia and D. capensis genomes to characterize the evolutionary differences between centromeric arrays of these species. Separate alignments of individual repeat units from both species revealed considerable SNP diversity and indel differences, both of which we infer to be related to mutational time since element duplications and/or movements37. Phylogenies of the repeat sequences parsed by chromosome and location revealed mixtures of positionally localized repeat clades as well as highly structurally mixed clades, suggesting both (1) local duplications of repeats that seed a given region (i.e., younger repeat lineages) followed by (2) movement of duplicates throughout the genomes thereafter (therefore signifying older repeat lineages), which then seed new centromeric foci and repeat the process (Fig. 3). Cape71 phylogeny (Fig. 3a) is characterized by multiple, same-chromosome clades on long branches, indicating that distinct subfamilies of monomers have arisen and undergone sustained, chromosome-specific amplification. In contrast, the Regi90 tree (Fig 3b) exhibits a more star-burst topology (very short internal branches and greater intermixing of colored tips) reflecting a recent, genome-wide expansion, with only very few clades of same-chromosome tips marking nascent local amplifications (Fig. 3b, right panel). Compared to the genome-wide mixing implied by the D. regia satDNA tree, the D. capensis pattern points to stronger, longer-lived local concerted evolution: repeat variants arose and expanded on particular chromosomes and have persisted as distinct subclades rather than being rapidly shuffled across the karyotype.

To assess chromosome-specific evolution of satellite DNA monomers, the tip labels were encoded with their chromosome of origin, and the resulting tree was midpoint-rooted to allow for relative branch-length comparisons. We then inspected terminal clades for non-random clustering of monomers by chromosome. In our analysis and graphic, each point represents the position of a monomer from the Cape71 tree (Fig. 3c), plotted at each chromosome relative midpoint (y-axis) and colored by root-distance order. All points lie at distinct vertical positions (one per chromosome) and display a variety of colors from the rank, indicating that different-age subfamilies lie at D. capensis centromeres, with early-splitting lineages having since been amplified on their respective chromosomes. A magnification of the chr19 centromeric region (Fig. 3d) once again reveals a narrow gradient of root-distance values within that ~20 kb interval. Filtering by monomers from the more monochromatic Cape71 tree (Fig 3d, bottom panel) does not change the gradient of root-distance ranks along the chromosomal landscape. Indeed, a mostly purple (recent) clade within that tight region reflects an early-splitting subfamily that has undergone sustained diversification (observable as variable terminal branch lengths). By contrast, the Regi90 plot shows every monomer scattered continuously along the length of each chromosome (Fig. 3e), colored across the full gradient from recent (purple) to ancient (yellow). This even distribution of young and old repeats along D. regia chromosomes reflects the starburst tree morphology, possibly indicating recent, genome-wide satDNA amplification followed by pervasive gene conversion that homogenized satellite sequences across all chromosomes. In the plot of D. regia Chr13, monomers of all root-distance ranks, from recent (purple) to deeply diverged (yellow), are evenly scattered along the entire chromosome length, likely reflecting high homogenization (Fig. 3f). However, when we isolate and plot only the monomers from the Fig. 3b sub-tree on Chr13 (right panel), they form a cohesive light-green cluster (Fig. 3f, bottom panel). Taking into account the topology of the tree, we infer that this cluster corresponds to a sudden amplification of a Regi90 monomer variant, perhaps expanding as a higher order repeat. It is worth noting that Regi90 monomers exhibit higher absolute divergence (longer root-to-tip distances; Fig. 3g) while displaying less chromosome-specific clustering and stronger karyotype-wide mixing than Cape71; conversely, Cape71 repeats, despite lower overall divergence, maintain more pronounced, array-specific subfamily structure and greater homogeneity within each chromosomal cluster.

We further characterized satellite DNA dynamics by conducting a similarity-based assessment within each major satellite DNA family, revealing generally low levels of homogenization across the arrays (Extended data Fig. 3). Interestingly, arrays of the centromeric Cape71 repeat in monocentric D. capensis showed greater homogenization levels across different chromosomes and within chromosomes (Extended data Fig. 3a). However, in D. regia the Regi90 arrays exhibited lower levels of similarity (approx. 75%) among chromosomes, mirroring the similarity observed within individual chromosomes (Extended data Fig. 3b). Notably, a large portion of the annotated satDNA in D. capensis was located in small unplaced scaffolds that were not linked to chromosomes, resulting in an underrepresented length of the arrays. From the total of 17 Mbp of Cape71 found in the genome of D. capensis using TideCluster, only 1.12 Mbp were annotated to chromosomes, likely due to the high homogenization of Cape71 hampering a contiguous assembly of these regions. In contrast, in D. regia, from a total of 3.8 Mb of annotated Regi90, 3.5 Mbp were placed into pseudochromosomes. These results are interesting as they suggest different rates of ongoing satDNA array size evolution and homogenization between monocentric D. capensis and holocentric D. regia.

sec.title: High repeat turnover in sundews
sec.p: Among the most abundant transposable elements, the genomes of D. regia and D. capensis were generally rich in Copia LTR retrotransposons38, with a special dominance of SIRE in D. capensis and TORK in D. regia (Extended data Fig. 4a). Although the majority of TEs in D. capensis were found in pericentromeric regions, a fraction of TORK elements was present in proximity to genes at a greater frequency than other TEs (Extended data Fig. 4b), similar to the patterns observed in D. regia (Extended data Fig. 4b, right panels). However, comparison of the distribution of different TEs in relation to the putative centromere positions revealed a preference for LINEs in D. capensis (Extended data Fig. 4b, upper left) and for the chromovirus REINA in D. regia (Extended data Fig. 4b, upper right). While chromoviruses preferentially target centromeric regions, LINE elements are often found pericentromerically39,40. In both cases, our results are in agreement with the assumption that Cape71 and Regi90 are the sequences associated with active centromeres.

Next, we aimed to characterize the dynamics and abundance of repetitive DNA across the Drosera genus. Although the specific composition of such DNAs is highly variable among angiosperm species, these sequences have proven to be major players in the evolution of eukaryotes41. For this purpose we included Illumina reads from an additional 10 Drosera species to analyze their repetitive fractions. Comparative analysis of the repeatomes of the 12 related species revealed that most of the elements found were shared only among species within the same clade. These similarities apparently reflect their phylogenetic relationships, as the sister species D. capensis and D. aliciae share a great diversity of repetitive elements. Apart from some families of transposable elements, such as ATHILA, SIRE or LINE, the satellite repeat Cape71 in D. capensis was found to be shared with D. aliciae (Extended data Fig. 4c). In addition, a closer look into the similarities between Cape71 and the remaining satellite repeats found among the 12 species revealed that Cape71 is related to both of the satDNA clusters found in D. spatulata (Extended data Fig 4d), thus reflecting the close evolutionary relationships of the three species. Another case of repeatome interrelationship that matches phylogeny was observed for D. anglica, D. filiformis and D. intermedia, where most of the different families of transposable elements were shared between these species but not with the other Drosera species studied. However, in this case, no shared satDNA repeats were found. Finally, great similarities among the elements of D. erythoriza and D. peltata were also found. Despite their different bursts of the RETAND and LINE families, these species shared most of their elements with their sister species D. menziesii (Extended data Fig. 4c). In addition, when the satDNA fractions of these three species were compared, we observed that the three taxa shared the same family of satDNA (Extended data Fig. 4d).

Interestingly, potentially holocentric species such as D. regia (Fig. 1e-h), D. scorpioides42 and D. broomensis are particularly divergent in their repetitive element compositions, having unique families of transposable elements and satDNAs in the majority of their clusters (Extended data Fig. 4c). In this regard, Regi90 does not share significant similarity with any of the other satellites analyzed, except for short stretches of homopolymer/mononucleotide repeats (AAAs)n (Extended data Fig. 4d, Extended data Fig. 2b,). In summary, our comparative analysis revealed that repetitive fractions experienced rapid turnover across the different clades of Drosera, which could be potentially linked with the different types of centromere organization found.

sec.title: Phylogeny and genome structural evolution of the Caryophyllales carnivore clade
Backbone phylogeny reveals unexpected relationships for D. regia and N. gracilis
sec.p: The genome of Nepenthes revealed a complex allopolyploid history (five subgenomes of x=8)13 that we suspected could confound inferences of relationships within Drosera. We therefore constructed a backbone phylogeny to model reticulate evolution among Caryophyllales carnivores by using conserved Benchmarking Universal Single-Copy Ortholog (BUSCO)43 gene sets to generate phylogenetic trees for Drosera, its close relatives, and selected outgroup angiosperms. Two sets of data were analyzed: nucleotide and inferred amino acid sequences for 22 and 50 species, respectively (Extended data Fig. 5). Distinct taxon samplings permitted evaluation of topological consistency under different possible outgroup effects. Phylogenetic reconstructions were made in two distinct ways: (1) maximum likelihood (ML) analyses44 of concatenated BUSCO alignments, and (2) ASTRAL species tree reconstruction45 summarizing all individual BUSCO gene trees. In all analyses, D. regia was resolved as sister to Aldrovanda plus Dionaea instead of to other species of Drosera. Nepenthes was usually resolved as sister to Drosera plus the snap-trapping carnivores, with the Drosophyllum plus Triphyophyllum/Ancistrocladus group forming that clade’s sister lineage (Extended data Fig. 5). These relationships for N. gracilis were incongruent with published results (that also employed nuclear-encoded BUSCO genes), which placed Nepenthes sister to the Drosophyllum plus Triphyophyllum/Ancistrocladus clade instead13. However, these relationships, forced to a bifurcating topology, are clearly inadequate for representing phylogenetic relationships among alloploids, which have hybrid origins46.

sec.title: Single copy genes display substantial gene tree conflict
sec.p: As a first approach to evaluating reticulate interrelationships, we analyzed taxonomically complete single-copy gene data for eight Caryophyllales carnivore species and their non-carnivorous relative, Ancistrocladus. Using such complete taxonomic representation, we visualized the results as a cloudogram47 to qualitatively highlight evidence for ancient admixture or incomplete lineage sorting that may have given rise to conflicting gene and species trees (Fig. 4). Here, it became apparent that D. regia has conflicting gene-tree relationships, wherein some loci favor a close relationship to Aldrovanda plus Dionaea, whereas others place D. regia as sister to the other Drosera species pair. Moreover, the gene tree conflict within the snap-trapping Aldrovanda plus Dionaea group suggests complex histories for these genera.

sec.title: Genome structure suggests complex polyploidy
sec.p: We further explored reticulate relationships within this Caryophyllales lineage by tracking genome structural evolutionary relationships. We used GENESPACE48 to perform gene-based synteny analyses between D. capensis and D. regia against available genomes from closely related outgroups: the pitcher plant N. gracilis, the Venus flytrap Dionaea muscipula, Ancistrocladus abbreviatus and Triphyophyllum peltatum. Synteny of the N. gracilis genome was highly conserved with the other Caryophyllales genomes studied. Ancistrocladus and Triphyophyllum shared a chromosomal fission followed by a tetraploidy event, which explains higher basic chromosome number of these species (x=9, Fig. 5a). Dionaea was also resolved as a tetraploid, but with two clearly different subgenomes (Fig. 5b, Extended data Fig. 6), indicating an allotetraploidy following lineage hybridization. Altogether our results suggest the basic chromosome number of the lineage to be x=8 (see also Mohn et al., 202328), with an ancestral karyotype similar to the dominant subgenome of N. gracilis.

The genome of N. gracilis bears five highly syntenic subgenomes, four of which are recessive in terms of genome expression and fractionation biases, while one is dominant13. Thus, for the sake of simplicity we compare only the dominant subgenome of N. gracilis with the other genomes. Remarkably, a high level of synteny was observed across most of the species’ genomes with a relative decrease in synteny found among sundews, especially D. capensis. Indeed, most D. regia chromosomes match N. gracilis dominant chromosomes in a 3:1 manner (Fig. 5a), consistent with the former species’ proposed hexaploid subgenome structure, which can in fact be phased 2 parts to 1 using Ks values (Fig. 5c). In contrast, the D. capensis genome was much more rearranged, showing much less syntenic block collinearity with the N. gracilis genome. Nonetheless, an unprecedented 6:1 match with the N. gracilis dominant subgenome supports a dodecaploid origin of its genome via tetraploidization of a hexaploid ancestor (Fig. 5a), in contrast to previous assumptions.

We were further able to underscore the paralogous/orthologous syntenic relationships within and between D. regia and N. gracilis using a concatenated D. regia and N. gracilis hybrid assembly and the SynMap application in CoGe49 (Fig. 6a,b). Three Ks coloration ranges for syntenic blocks in the dot plot matched WGM or speciation events. Within D. regia, the 2:1 subgenome phasing was apparent as the purple:cyan blocks, with the purple block – plus the diagonal – representing the two youngest of the three subgenomes, and the single cyan block the oldest (see also Fig. 5c). These blockwise relationships can be discerned counting either horizontally or vertically. Within N. gracilis, its 4:1 subgenome structure can be recognized as four blocks on the dot plot plus the diagonal, and its pentuplicate structure is even clearer in its 5:3 blockwise to D. regia. From colorations in the Ks histogram (Fig. 6b), it can be seen that both of the D. regia events (purple younger that cyan) occurred more recently than those of N. gracilis (green and orange), with the species split between D. regia and N. gracilis (also orange) as old as some of the Nepenthes-specific subgenomes resulting from the latter taxon’s two lineage-specific tetraploidies. Remarkably, window-wise fractionation bias calculations49,50 (Fig. 6c-e) demonstrated that all three D. regia subgenomes share strong and highly similar post-polyploidy gene retention profiles with the dominant subgenome of N. gracilis, the recessive subgenomes of which are much more heavily fractionated. As such, it is plausible that the N. gracilis dominant subgenome shares close ancestry with a near relative of D. regia.

We investigated whether the hexaploid ancestry of D. capensis is shared with D. regia by conducting additional synteny analyses using ksrates51 and targeted GENESPACE analyses. Despite extensive post-polyploid rearrangements in D. capensis, some chromosomes shared between D. regia and D. capensis (denoted by pairs of different colors detailed in Extended data Fig. 8) displayed plausibly shared fusion events, suggesting common ancestral genomic restructuring that occurred prior to their species split, i.e., in their common ancestor. ksrates analysis further confirmed that the allotetraploidy in Dionaea and the hexaploidy in both D. regia and D. capensis predated their respective species splits, which points toward shared triplicate structure for D. regia and D. capensis followed by D. capensis subsequently undergoing an additional lineage-specific tetraploidy event (Extended data Fig. 9).

Furthermore, congruent with the SynMap Ks coloration in Fig. 6a,b, ksrates revealed a species split between N. gracilis and the Dionaea-Drosera group far earlier than the phylogenetic splits among the latter.

Nonetheless, definitively asserting a single, shared hexaploidy event for both D. regia and D. capensis based solely on shared rearrangements is complex. While shared rearrangements are a useful, parsimonious proxy for inferring a common polyploid origin52,53, this association is not unassailable. Given triplicate structure in both Drosera species, the probability of observing seemingly shared rearrangements by chance, or at sites prone to recurrent breakage, is low but cannot be entirely excluded. Interpretation of a shared hexaploidy is further nuanced by phylogenetic evidence (e.g., our BUSCO topologies; Extended data Fig. 5) suggesting D. regia’s sister-group relationship to Dionaea, rather than to the Drosera clade that contains D. capensis. Future work should include the analysis of additional Drosera genomes to robustly resolve the precise timing and shared ancestry of one or more hexaploidy events. This will allow a clearer understanding of whether pervasive fusions in D. regia occurred before or after the evolution of holocentricity, and if reversal from holocentricity to monocentricity in D. capensis is plausible.

In summary, our inferred hybrid origin of D. regia and D. capensis likely involves other Drosera species in addition to the Dionaea lineage, as is apparent from the extreme conflict among independent phylogenies based on a large collection of single-copy genes (Fig. 4). Originating from three x=8 ancestral subgenomes, the immediate progenitor of D. regia was likely n=24 prior to chromosomal rearrangements that led to its modern n=17 karyotype. The D. capensis genome also contains an underlying triplicate structure, many species-specific chromosome fusion events, and a recent, lineage-specific WGM that led to its dodecaploid karyotype (Fig. 5a). Triphyophyllum peltatum includes, through a lineage-specific WGM, n=18 chromosomes descendant from a x=9 progenitor derived from a chromosomal fission event within the Caryophyllales x=8 ancestor. Ancistrocladus is sister to Triphyophyllum and shares its karyotype (Fig. 5a).

Based on our backbone phylogenetic tree analyses, syntenic relationships, subgenome fractionation patterns, Ks distributions, and chromosome numbers, we offer a tentative scenario (Fig. 7) for reticulate allopolyploid interrelationships among the Caryophyllales carnivore genomes analyzed here that will require additional high-quality genome assemblies for validation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We present chromosome-scale assemblies for Drosera capensis and D. regia, two carnivorous sundews that exemplify the rare coexistence of divergent centromere architectures, monocentric and holocentric, within a single genus. This unusual pairing provides a powerful system for investigating how centromere type influences genome architecture, repeat evolution, and chromosomal behavior, or conversely, how genome dynamics may shape centromere evolutionary transitions.

Integrating cytogenetic, genome sequence, and 3D chromatin conformation data, we confirm monocentricity in D. capensis and holocentricity in D. regia, an infrageneric contrast otherwise reported in plants only in the parasitic genus Cuscuta. While holocentricity has evolved independently across angiosperms54–56, the trait is otherwise infrafamilial only. These findings underscore the need for high-resolution chromosomal and cytological assays when inferring centromere types, particularly in groups with complex karyotypes. Indeed, the recent discovery of extended regional centromeres in the related Dionaea muscipula57 suggests a continuum in centromere organization across Droseraceae, from monocentric to extended regional to holocentric forms, potentially shaped by lineage-specific responses to whole-genome duplication and the “genomic shock” caused by TE activation58.

Structurally, D. capensis and D. regia exhibit striking divergence in centromeric repeat profiles. The satDNA Cape71 is localized and structured in D. capensis, consistent with point centromere function, while Regi90 in D. regia is dispersed along chromosomes, resembling other repeat-based holocentromeres24,26. The absence of CENH3 and KNL1 immunosignals in D. regia may also support a non-canonical centromeric structure defined by unusual epigenetic mechanisms. Species-specific TE enrichments, SIRE in D. capensis and Tork in D. regia, may contribute to centromere remodeling, influencing chromatin context and kinetochore plasticity.

Comparative repeat profiling across the Drosera genus reveals high variability in satDNA and TE composition, consistent with rapid repeat turnover and centromere repositioning, possibly in response to polyploidy. These patterns reinforce emerging models linking transposon dynamics to the restructuring of plant centromeres and overall genome fluidity.

Synteny analyses, particularly between the shared chromosomal rearrangements in both D. capensis (dodecaploid) and D. regia (hexaploid) suggest a possible common hexaploid ancestor that had already undergone extensive chromosomal fusions. However, the two species exhibit sharply divergent structural outcomes: holocentric D. regia retained this ancestral karyotype with minimal rearrangements, whereas monocentric D. capensis experienced substantial chromosomal reshuffling. The observed divergence following whole genome duplication suggests that centromere type may influence genome stability, with holocentricity potentially buffering against large-scale rearrangements.

It is remarkable that such divergent chromosomal architectures evolved within Drosera, a genus embedded within the morphologically and physiologically complex Caryophyllales carnivorous plant clade. This monophyletic lineage encompasses species with diverse trapping strategies: flypaper traps in Drosera, Drosophyllum, and Triphyophyllum; snap-traps in Dionaea and Aldrovanda; and pitfall traps in Nepenthes14. Within this context, our findings could suggest that centromere and polyploid mechanistic diversity may correlate with ecological diversification or even promote it, which would raise questions about the interplay between chromosomal mechanics, genome architecture, and adaptation.

Together, our results demonstrate that centromere organization, polyploid history, and repeat dynamics jointly shape genome evolution in Drosera. The presence of both holocentric and monocentric species, each likely derived from the same, distinctly chromosomally fused hexaploid ancestor yet diverging markedly in chromosome structural outcomes, points to centromere type as a possible determinant of post-polyploid genome trajectories. Future studies should investigate how these architectural differences influence chromosome segregation, recombination, and gene expression, ultimately shaping adaptation in diverse plant lineages.

sec.title: Plant materials and genome sequencing
sec.p: In vitro cultures of D. regia and D. capensis were initiated from seeds derived from plants maintained in the carnivorous plant collection at the Red Manejo Biotecnológico de Recursos, Instituto de Ecología, A.C., Xalapa, Veracruz, Mexico. For superficial disinfection, seeds were placed in filter paper envelopes (Whatman No. 1, 110 mm diameter) and submerged in sterile distilled water for 30 minutes. They were then soaked in a 10% (v/v) commercial bleach solution (1.8% NaOCl) containing two drops of Tween-80 per 100 mL (Sigma, St. Louis, MO) for 10 minutes. This was followed by four rinses with sterile distilled water under aseptic conditions. The disinfected seeds were sown in 125-mL baby food jars containing 25 mL of half-strength MS medium (Murashige and Skoog, 1962), supplemented with 30 g·L−1 sucrose. The pH was adjusted to 5.0 ± 0.1 using 0.5 N NaOH and 0.5 N HCl prior to the addition of 7.5 g·L−1 Agar, Plant TC (Caisson A111), followed by autoclaving at 1.2 kg·cm−2 and 120 °C for 15 minutes. Cultures were incubated in a growth chamber at 25 ± 1 °C under a 16-hour photoperiod provided by LED lamps (50 μmol·m−2·s−1). Plants obtained from germinated seeds were subcultured every 3–4 months on the same medium to promote growth and multiplication.

High-molecular-weight DNA was extracted from nuclei isolated from the young leaves of Drosera species, following the protocol by Steinmüller and Apel, 198659. To reduce contamination from chloroplast and mitochondrial DNA, nuclei were first collected from a 60% Percoll (Invitrogen) density gradient after centrifugation at 4000g for 10 minutes at 4°C. Next, high-quality megabase-sized DNA was obtained using the MagAttract HMW DNA Kit (Qiagen). Before library preparation for sequencing, the integrity of the high molecular weight (HMW) DNA was confirmed using pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (CHEF-DRIII system, Bio-Rad), as described elsewhere60. For library preparation, 10 µg of DNA were sheared to a fragment size range of 10–40 kb using a Covaris g-TUBE. The resulting fragment distribution was verified by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis. The sheared DNA was purified using 0.45× AMPure PB beads (Pacific Biosciences) following the manufacturer’s protocol.

Library preparation For the PacBio RS II instrument was carried out according to the PacBio 20 kb SMRTbell Template Preparation Protocol, using 5 µg of the sheared DNA as input material. After preparation, the library size distribution was analyzed on an Agilent DNA 12000 Bioanalyzer chip to determine the appropriate size-selection cut-off. Libraries were size-selected with a Sage Science BluePippin system, employing a dye-free 0.75% agarose cassette and a 15 kb cut-off. The selected libraries were reanalyzed on the Bioanalyzer to confirm size distribution. Two libraries per species were prepared for D. capensis and D. regia The D. capensis library was sequenced on two SMRT cells of the PacBio RSII single-molecule sequencing platform at loading concentrations of 0.15 nM and 0.2 nM, respectively. The D. regia library was sequenced on eight SMRT cells at a loading concentration of 0.2 nM. For Illumina sequencing of D. capensis, D. regia and the ten additional Drosera species, the Illumina HiSeq 2500 (rapid run, 2x250bp; https://www.illumina.com/documents/products/datasheets/datasheet_hiseq2500.pdf) was employed.

sec.title: Genome assembly and Hi-C scaffolding
sec.p: The 2x250bp Illumina reads were first filtered for adapter sequences using Trimmomatic v0.3661. A hybrid assembly including the filtered reads and PacBio RS II reads was then carried out using MaSuRCA v3.2.162. The contig-level assemblies were evaluated for completeness with BUSCO v3.0.243 using the embryophyta odb9 database, and for contiguity, using QUAST v4.363.

Dovetail Hi-C reads were first mapped to the contig file obtained from the MaSuRCA assembler using BWA64 following the hic-pipeline (https://github.com/esrice/hic-pipeline). Hi-C scaffolding was performed using 3D-DNA pipeline65,66 with default parameters using ‘GATC, GAATC, GATTC, GAGTC, GACTC’ as restriction sites. After testing several minimum mapping quality values of bam alignments, the final scaffolding was performed with MAPQ10. Following the automated scaffolding by 3D-DNA, several rounds of visual assembly correction guided by Hi-C heatmaps were performed. When regions showed multiple contact patterns, manual re-organization of the scaffolds was performed with Juicebox and 3D-DNA assembly pipeline65 to correct position/orientation and to obtain the pseudomolecules.

sec.title: Transcriptome sequencing and genome annotation
sec.p: Total RNA was extracted from D. capensis leaf tissues and petioles. Sample preparation employed a single stranded mRNA library kit, and libraries were subsequently sequenced using an Illumina HiSeq instrument. We obtained a total data of 105,784,845 read pairs. To generate our transcriptome assembly, we first merged the RNA-Seq data from the two tissues. We then assembled one de novo transcriptome using transAbyss v2.0.167. In transAbyss, we used multiple k-mers (33-75) in steps of 2 to generate multiple assemblies before merging them all into a single large set. We then assembled a second de novo transcriptome using Trinity v2.6.668 using the default k-mer size of 25. We generated one reference-guided transcriptome by first mapping the RNA-Seq reads against the reference D. capensis genome using HISAT2 v.2.1.069 and then assembling the transcriptome using StringTie v.1.3.4c70. We then passed the three transcriptome assemblies to EvidentialGene v2017.12.2171 which produced a final high confidence transcriptome assembly.

For repeat masking, we first generated a de novo repeat library for the D. capensis genome using RepeatModeler v1.0.972 and then masked the genome using RepeatMasker v4.0.773. For gene model prediction, the transcriptome assembly was first splice-aligned against the unmasked reference D. capensis genome using PASA v2.2.074 to generate ORFs. Secondly, ab initio gene model prediction was carried out using BRAKER v.2.0.375, which internally used the reference aligned RNA-Seq data and Genemark-ET to train AUGUSTUS v3.375,76 for its final prediction. Additionally, the self-training Genemark-ES v.4.3377 was run independently to generate a second set of predictions. Finally the 2 prediction tracks and two spliced-alignment tracks were passed to the combiner tool Evidence Modeler v1.1.174 with highest weights to transcriptome evidence and lowest weights to Genemark-ES to generate a final high confidence gene prediction set. This final prediction set was re-run through PASA to update the gene models, add UTRs and identify and generate alternate spliced models.

For D. regia, the D. capensis transcriptome assembly was used as evidence for training purposes. First, the assembly was splice-aligned against the D. regia genome using PASA v.2.2.074 to generate ORFs. Additionally, Arabidopsis thaliana gene models were aligned against the genome using exonerate v2.2.078. Genemark-ES v4.3377 was then used to generate one set of predictions. BRAKER v2.0.375 was used in the protein mode where the D. capensis gene models were aligned against the D. regia genome using GenomeThreader v1.7.1 (https://genomethreader.org/), and that set was used to train BRAKER v2.0.3 to generate a second set of gene models. AUGUSTUS v3.375,76 was run independently using D. capensis parameters to generate a third set of predictions for D. regia. All of these gene predictions were then passed to Evidence Modeler v1.1.174 to generate a single high confidence gene prediction set. This set was once again passed through PASA to update the gene models with UTR regions and also to generate the splice variants.

sec.title: Synteny analysis
sec.p: Synteny analyses were performed with GENESPACE (https://github.com/jtlovell/GENESPACE)48. To identify shared chromosomal rearrangements, we first identified all end-to-end fusions of non-homoeologous chromosomes within the D. regia genome. For each such fusion event, we then extracted corresponding genomic regions from D. capensis that involved the same ancestral Nepenthes-like chromosomes. Shared rearrangements were inferred when the breakpoint boundary regions in D. regia precisely matched the syntenic block locations in D. capensis that represented these fusions.

Further synteny analyses were performed using the CoGe SynMap platform (https://genomevolution.org/coge/SynMap.pl)49. Synteny plots were obtained using the following steps: (1) using the Last tool, (2) synteny analysis was performed using DAGChainer, using 20 genes as the maximum distance between two matches (-D) and 5 genes as the minimum number of aligned pairs (-A). Then (3) either default (no syntenic depth) or Quota Align (with syntenic depth) was used with overlap distance of 40 genes, and (4) orthologous and paralogous blocks were differentiated according to the synonymous substitution rate (Ks) using CoGe-integrated CodeML, and represented with different colors in the dot plot. FractBias50 was run using Quota Align window size of 100 for all genes in the target genome, with a syntenic depth ratio of 12:12 with maximum query and target chromosome numbers of 64 each for the concatenated D. regia-N. gracilis genome assembly.

For the characterization of the regions involved in fusions, we followed Hofstatter et al, 202224. The synteny alignment between D. regia genome and N. gracilis dominant subgenome obtained in GENESPACE allowed us to pin the putative regions around the borders of the fusion events. In order, to identify the underlying sequences at the fusion regions, we loaded annotation features for genes, TEs, and tandem repeats on synteny alignments. This allowed us to detect the sequence types in the putative fused regions. Further inspection and characterization of such regions were done by checking the genome coordinates and annotation features with Geneious (https://www.geneious.com).

sec.title: Subgenome-aware phasing of D. regia and Dionaea muscipula genomes
sec.p: We used SubPhaser79 (default parameters) to phase and partition the subgenomes of D. regia and D. muscipula genomes simultaneously by assigning chromosomes to subgenomes based on differential repetitive k-mers. Additionally, Ks distributions of homeologous duplicate gene pairs were extracted from CoGe SynMap calculations (above) to generate density plots for each triplet of D. regia ancestral chromosomes. Density plots were generated in R using the tidyverse80, ggplot281, RColorBrewer82, ggridges83, and ggpmisc84 packages.

sec.title: ksrates analysis
sec.p: ksrates version 1.1.485 was used to position species splits relative to polyploidy events. Coding sequence (CDS) fasta files were extracted using AGAT version 1.4.086. Paralogous Ks peaks were generated for the following focal species: Ancistrocladus abbreviatus (this study), Dionaea muscipula (this study), D. capensis (this study), D. regia (this study), Nepenthes gracilis13, and Triphyophyllum peltatum (this study). Beta vulgaris (GCA_026745355.1), Coffea canephora87, Gelsemium elegans (CoGe id64491), and Spinacia oleracea (GCA_020520425.1) were also included in the analysis, but not as focal species. Orthologous Ks peaks were generated for each required species pair.

For the tree topology used in ksrates, OrthoFinder v2.5.588 was run with default settings to generate a tree for all species listed above. Each annotation was reduced to the longest isoform and proteins were extracted using AGAT version 1.4.086. The species tree inference was performed with STAG89, which uses the proportion of species trees derived from single-locus gene trees supporting each bipartition as its measure of support, and rooted using STRIDE90.

sec.title: Repeat characterization
sec.p: DANTE and DANTE-LTR retrotransposon identification (Galaxy Version 3.5.1.1) pipelines91 were used to identify full-length LTR retrotransposons in the assembled genomes of D. capensis and D. regia, using a set of protein domains from REXdb92. All complete LTR-RTs contain GAG, PROT, RT, RH and INT domains, including some lineages encoding additional domains, such as chromodomains (CHD and CHDCR) from chromoviruses or ancestral RNase H (aRH) from Tat elements. DANTE_LTR retrotransposon filtering (Galaxy Version 3.5.1.1) was used to search for high quality retrotransposons, those with no cross-similarity between distinct lineages. This tool produced a GFF3 output file with detailed annotations of the LTR-RTs identified in the genome and a summary table with the numbers of the identified elements. Overall repeat composition was calculated excluding clusters of organelle DNA (chloroplast and mitochondrial DNA).

Tandem repeat sequences were identified using RepeatExplorer2 (https://repeatexplorer-elixir.cerit-sc.cz/) and further verified using the TideCluster pipeline (https://github.com/kavonrtep/TideCluster)93. All putative tandem sequences were compared for homology using DOTTER. These tandem sequences were individually mapped to the genome by BLAST94, with 95% similarity in Geneious (https://www.geneious.com). The mapped sequence files were converted to BED and used as an input track for a genome-wide overview with ShinyCircos95 using a 100kb window.

Comparative repeatome analysis of Drosera genomes was made using Illumina reads from the species listed in Extended Data Table 1. First, reads were filtered by quality with 95% of bases equal to or above the quality cut-off value of 10 using the RepeatExplorer2 pipeline (https://repeatexplorer-elixir.cerit-sc.cz/)93. The clustering was performed using the default settings of 90% similarity over 55% of the read length. For the comparative analyses, we performed an all-to-all similarity comparison across all species following the same approach. Because genome sizes are unknown for some analyzed species, each set of reads was down-sampled to 1,000,000 for each species. The automated annotations of repeat clusters obtained by RepeatExplorer2 were manually inspected and reviewed, followed by recalculation of the genomic proportion of each repeat type when appropriate.

sec.title: Immunostaining and FISH
sec.p: Flower buds of D. capensis and D. regia at various developmental stages were harvested and immediately fixed in freshly prepared 4% formaldehyde in Tris buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 10 mM EDTA, and 0.5% Triton X-100), when immunostaining was intended, or ethanol-acetic acid (3:1 v/v) when only FISH was performed.

For immunostaining, fixation was carried out under vacuum infiltration for at least 15 minutes at room temperature, followed by an additional 45 minutes of incubation without vacuum. Fixed tissues were washed twice in 1× phosphate-buffered saline (1x PBS) at 4 °C until further processing. For enzymatic digestion, individual fixed buds were incubated in a solution containing 2% (w/v) cellulase (Onozuka R-10) and 2% (w/v) pectinase (Sigma) prepared in 1× PBS. Digestion was performed at 37 °C for 1 hour to facilitate cell wall degradation and release of nuclei. Following digestion, the softened tissue was gently macerated on a clean slide and squashed under the coverslip. Chromosome spreads were washed in 1× PBS for 5 minutes, followed by incubation in PBS-T1 buffer (1× PBS, 0.5% Triton X-100, pH 7.4) for 25 minutes. After two additional 5-minute washes in PBS, slides were incubated in PBS-T2 buffer (1× PBS, 0.1% Tween 20, pH 7.4) for 30 minutes. Primary antibody incubation was performed overnight at 4 °C using rabbit anti-CENH3 (specific for each species; Extended data Fig.2), rabbit anti-KNL196 (GenScript, NJ, USA) and mouse anti α-tubulin (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO; catalog number T6199) diluted 1:1,000 in blocking buffer (3% BSA, 1x PBS, 0.1% Tween 20, pH 7.4). Slides were then washed twice in 1x PBS (5 minutes each) and once in PBS-T2 (5 minutes), followed by incubation with secondary antibodies for at least 1 hour at room temperature. As the secondary antibody, goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody conjugated with Alexa Fluor 488 (Invitrogen; catalog number A27034), goat anti-rabbit conjugated with Rhodamine Red X (Jackson ImmunoResearch, catalog number: 111-295-144) or goat anti-mouse conjugated with Alexa Fluor 488 (Jackson ImmunoResearch; catalog number 115-545-166) were used in a 1:500 dilution. Final washes included two rounds in PBS and one in PBS-T2, each for 5 minutes. Slides were then mounted for fluorescence microscopy. Microscopic images were recorded using a Zeiss Axiovert 200M microscope equipped with a Zeiss AxioCam CCD. Images of at least 5 cells were analyzed using the ZEN software (Carl Zeiss GmbH).

For FISH experiments, material fixation was performed for 2 days at 4 °C, washed in ice-cold water, and digested in a solution of 4% cellulase (Onozuka R10, Serva Electrophoresis, Heidelberg, Germany), 2% pectinase, and 0.4% pectolyase Y23 (both MP Biomedicals, Santa Ana, CA) in 0.01 M citrate buffer (pH 4.5) for 60 min at 37 °C. The digested material was transferred to a drop of 45% acetic acid, macerated and squashed under a coverslip. FISH was performed using either oligonucleotide probes that were 5′-labeled with Cy3 during their synthesis (D. regia Regi90 (Cy3)-CAAGTATTTCAATGGAAATGGTGAAATAACATGTTTTTACACCTATTTCC;

D. capensis Cape71 (Cy3)-CCCTTTAAATGAGCTTAAAACACTCAAAACCCCTTGAAAAGGCTAAAAAC). FISH was performed as described in Macas, et al. 200797, with hybridization and washing temperatures adjusted to account for AT/GC content and hybridization stringency allowing for 10–20% mismatches. The slides were counterstained with 2 µg/mL DAPI in Vectashield (Vector) mounting medium. The images of at least 10 cells were captured as described above.

sec.title: Satellite DNA phylogeny
sec.p: Centromere tracks were generated using the consensus sequences of the main satellite repeats identified using TideCluster, and the coordinates of Cape71 and Regi90 satDNA polymers were used to guide sequence extraction in Geneious Prime (https://www.geneious.com). In total, 5,371 Cape71 and 18,178 Regi90 were extracted from D. capensis and D. regia, respectively. The collected centromeric repeat sequences were aligned using MAFFT v7.49098. Phylogenetic trees were inferred using FastTree v2.1.1199 under the generalized time-reversible (GTR) model. Resulting trees were visualized and annotated using the Interactive Tree of Life (iTOL) web server100, with colors corresponding to their chromosome of origin.

The phylogenetic trees were imported into R using the ape package101. Tip labels included chromosome ID and genomic coordinates. Genomic positions of sampled tips were plotted using ggplot281 as normalized positions (relative to chromosome length) in order to show the spatial distribution of tips along individual chromosomes. Tips were plotted using ggplot2, with color representing the order of appearance in the tree (NodeOrder), allowing assessment of how phylogenetic relationships correlate with genomic location. All analyses and plotting were performed in R (version 4.1.2) using the packages ape101, dplyr102, ggplot281, and viridis (https://sjmgarnier.github.io/viridis/).

sec.title: Species tree inference with BUSCO genes
sec.p: To extract BUSCO genes, we collected coding sequence sets from sequenced genomes as well as previously assembled transcriptomes103 (Extended Data Table 2). We identified eudicot-conserved single-copy genes with BUSCO v5.3.2 (https://gitlab.com/ezlab/busco). Genes classified as single-copy (S) or fragmented (F) were retained, whereas those classified as duplicated (D) or missing (M) were considered absent, as described previously. Protein sequences were aligned with MAFFT v7.508 (https://mafft.cbrc.jp/alignment/server/index.html), trimmed with ClipKIT v2.1.1 (https://github.com/JLSteenwyk/ClipKIT), and back-translated to codons with CDSKIT v0.10.10 (https://github.com/kfuku52/cdskit) to produce in-frame nucleotide alignments. For each gene, nucleotide and protein maximum-likelihood trees were inferred with IQ-TREE v2.2.5 using GTR+R4 and LG+R4 models, respectively. Individual gene trees were then used for coalescent species-tree inference with ASTRAL v5.7.845. Concatenated nucleotide and protein alignments, generated by catfasta2phyml v2018-09-28 (https://github.com/nylander/catfasta2phyml), served as additional input to IQ-TREE44 with the same substitution models. Amborella trichopoda was specified as the outgroup.

caption.p: Two datasets were examined: nucleotide coding sequences or inferred amino acids from 22 species or 50 species. Both methods consistently placed D. regia as the sister group to Aldrovanda plus Dionaea, rather than to other Drosera species. Nepenthes was generally recovered as sister to Drosera and the snap-trapping lineages, while the clade containing Drosophyllum and Triphyophyllum/Ancistrocladus formed their sister group.

caption.title: ksrates synonymous substitutions calibration clarifies split times and polyploidy events for D. regia, D. capensis, and Dionaea muscipula.
caption.p: Here, focal species are (top to bottom) D. regia, Dionaea, and D. capensis. Colorations for events are the same for D. regia and Dionaea; they share the blue tetraploidy, which is the allotetraploidy still visible in Dionaea. For D. regia, one third of its hexaploid genome matches Dionaea; the hexaploidy was likely time-coincident with Dionaea’s allotetraploidy, with D. regia’s third subgenome possibly being one of the two original Dionaea parents. The species splits for D. regia, Dionaea, and D. capensis (aligned at the orange vertical line) are also time-coincident, lying after the allotetraploidy and allohexaploidy events. While the D. capensis-focused analysis at the bottom appears different at a glance, it is not. Due to how the ksrates software handles plotting, the most recent tetraploidy is blue, and it occurred after D. capensis split from D. regia and Dionaea (orange line). With color coding changed, the older event shared with D. regia and Dionaea is red and is barely visible, with its remains in the modern D. capensis genome having been overlaid by an extremely recent tetraploidy event.

caption.title: Differential structural rearrangements shaped the evolution of mono- and holocentric Drosera genomes.
caption.p: (a) Synteny comparison of the dominant subgenome of decaploid N. gracilis (8 chromosomes) against tetraploid Ancistrocladus abbreviatus and Triphyophyllum peltatum (below Nepenthes), allotetraploid Dionaea muscipula, hexaploid and holocentric D. regia and the dodecaploid and monocentric D. capensis (above Nepenthes). Dionaea is doubled compared to Nepenthes, and very little rearranged; D. regia and D. capensis share triplicate structure and some chromosomal fusions compared to Nepenthes. D. capensis shows a further duplication and complex rearrangements. (b) Subphaser PCA plot based on a concatenation of the Dionaea and D. regia assemblies demonstrates that Dionaea is an allopolyploid of subgenomes 2 (cyan) and 3 (purple), and that D. regia (yellow) has evolved distinct k-mers since its divergence from the former species (see also Extended data Fig. 6). (c) Density Ks plot of D. regia homeologous gene pairs clearly phases D. regia’s triplicate subgenome structure into a 2:1 pattern. Chromosomes 1 and 3 match, whereas chromosome 2 represents an older subgenome at higher Ks (x-axis = log10 Ks; y-axis = density; see also Extended data Fig. 7). (d) Analysis of Regi90 repeat localization (black bars) at chromosomal fusion points found in D. regia. Note the high frequency of Regi90 found at fusion regions. The colored rectangles represent syntenic blocks to ancestral N. gracilis chromosomes in panel a. Note the black bar at the break point of chromosome 15.

caption.title: Ancestral subgenome sharing between Nepenthes and D. regia.
caption.p: (a) Self:self syntenic dot plot of a concatenated assembly of D. regia and N. gracilis, (b) colored by with Ks. (c) FractBias plots showing a close relationship, through very similar gene retention profiles, among all three D. regia subgenomes and the Nepenthes dominant subgenome. The four recessive Nepenthes chromosomes (generated by two tetraploidy events) have much lower gene retention profiles and are shown in gray. Views (c-e) show the three different possible chromosome pairs mapped to D. regia chromosomes 1, 2 and 3, respectively; Nepenthes dominant chromosome 2 is their syntenic match.

caption.title: Phylogenetic network hypothesis for interrelationships among the six Caryophyllales genomes under study.
caption.p: An x=8 ancestor is proposed. All other Caryophyllales carnivores share Nepenthes’ x=8 ancestral subgenome, or a modification of it. Dionaea is an x=16 allotetraploid hybrid of two different 8-chromosome ancestors. D. regia appears to share the two subgenomes of that species, along with a third subgenome joining in to yield another hybrid lineage, an allohexaploid one that precludes phylogenetic depiction as deriving from a single phylogenetic split. Polyploidy events, chromosome fusions and fissions, numbers of subgenomes, haploid chromosome numbers, and admixture (hybridization) edges are denoted as in the legend. The first and second grey panels detail the possible events that gave rise to the modern D. regia genome. In the upper panels, two successive hybridization events produce an ancestral D. regia that possesses three distinct subgenomes: two closely related subgenomes (blue rectangles) and one divergent subgenome (orange rectangle). In the lower panel, a single cross between an ancestral D. regia lineage and an ancestral Dionaea lineage gives rise to modern D. regia.
